slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: How does β sound and what is it called?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! Remember that Beta sounds like the "b" in book.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite. The correct answer was beta like book.
slides.failureMsg: The correct answer was beta like book

slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: Which of these are gammas?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! You've identified gamma, Γ γ, pronounced like the "g" in grammar.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite.The correct answer was Γ γ.

slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: How does γ sound and what is it called?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer!
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite. Remember that gamma sounds like the "g" in grammar.

slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: Which of these is an alpha?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! You've identified alpha, α, pronounced like the "a" in arachnid.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite. The correct answer was α.

slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: What is the order of these letters in the alphabet?
slides.successMsg: Correctomundo!
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite.The correct answer was α, β, γ.
slides.failureMsg: The correct answer was α, β, γ.

slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: How does η sound and what is it called?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! Remember that Eta sounds like the "η" in hair.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite. The correct answer was eta like hair.
slides.failureMsg: The correct answer was eta like hair.

slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: Which of these are zdeta?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! You've identified zdeta, Ζ ζ, pronounced like the "zd" in wisdom.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite. The correct answer was Ζ ζ

slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: How does δ sound and what is it called?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! Remember that delta sounds like the "δ" in door.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite. The correct answer was delta like door.
slides.failureMsg: The correct answer was delta like door.

slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: How does λ sound and what is it called?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer!
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite. Remember that lambda sounds like the "λ" in long.

slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: Which of these is a theta?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! You've identified theta, θ, pronounced like the "th" in thunder.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite. The correct answer was "th" like thunder

slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: What is the order of these letters in the alphabet?
slides.successMsg: You're right!
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite. The correct answer was δ, ε, ζ, η
slides.failureMsg: The correct answer was δ, ε, ζ, η

slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: How does κ sound and what is it called?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer!
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite. Remember that gamma sounds like the "κ" in coat.
slides.failureMsg: The correct answer was kappa like coat.

slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: Which of these is a iota?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! You've identified theta, ι, pronounced like the "i" in east.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite. The correct answer was "i" like east

slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: What is the order of these letters in the alphabet?
slides.successMsg: Correct!
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite. The correct answer was θ, ι, κ, λ.
slides.failureMsg: The correct answer was span lang="grc">θ, ι, κ, λ.

slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: How does ν sound and what is it called?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer!
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite. Remember that Nu sounds like the "n" in book.

slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: Which of these are rho?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! You've identified rho, Ρ ρ, pronounced like the "r" in rose.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite. The correct answer was Ρ ρ

slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: What is the order of these letters in the alphabet?
slides.successMsg: Awesome!
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite The correct answer was μ, ν, ο, π.
slides.failureMsg: The correct answer was μ, ν, ο, π.

slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: Which of these are a sigma?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! You've identified sigma, σ,ς, pronounced like the "s" in signal.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite. The correct answer is "s" like signal.

slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: How does ρ sound and what is it called?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer!
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite. The correct answer was "r" like rose.

slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: What is the order of these letters in the alphabet?
slides.successMsg: You're awesome!
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite. The correct answer was ρ, ς, τ, υ.
slides.failureMsg: The correct answer was ρ, ς, τ, υ.

slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: Which of these is a tau?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! You've identified tau, τ, pronounced like the "t" in tower.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite. The correct answer was "t" like tower.

slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: How does χ sound and what is it called?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! Remember that Khi sounds like the "k" in kiosk.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite. The correct answer was "k" like kiosk.

slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: Which of these is a Phi?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! You've identified fi, φ, pronounced like the "f" in flower.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite. The correct answer was "f" like flower.

slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: Which of these are omega?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! You've identified omega, Ω ω, pronounced like the "o" in ostrich.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite. The correct answer was "ω", "Ω".

slides.title: Identify the letter!
slides.question: What is the order of these letters in the alphabet?
slides.successMsg: You're awesome!
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite. The correct answer was φ, χ, ψ, ω.
slides.failureMsg: The correct answer was φ, χ, ψ, ω.

slides.title: Pronounciation Challenge!
slides.question: How would you pronounce ὁδός, way?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! You remembered that ὁ is pronounced like "hoh".
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite Remember that ὁ is pronounced like "hoh" because of the rough breathing.

slides.title: Pronounciation Challenge!
slides.question: How would you spell Hellēnes, Greeks?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! You remembered that the He sound must come from a rough breathing, such as ῾´Ε.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite Remember that in Greek, the H sound must come from a rough breathing, such as ῾´Ε.

slides.title: Pronounciation Challenge!
slides.question: How would you pronounce ὀλιγαρχία, oligarchy?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! You remembered that ὀ sounds like 'oh', because of its smooth breathing.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite Remember that smooth breathings don't affect pronunciation. So ὀλιγαρχία simply sounds like 'Oh-li-gar-khia'.

slides.title: What is the long version of ε, epsilon?
slides.question: What is the long version of ε, epsilon?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! You remembered that η, eta, is the long version of ε, epsilon.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite Remember that η, eta, is the long version of ε, epsilon.

slides.title: Vowel Lengths!
slides.question: Which of these vowels can NOT be long?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! These are all vowels that are either short, or can be short or long.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite Remember that ω and η can only be long vowels. The short vowels are α, ε, ι, ο, υ.

slides.title: Vowel Lengths!
slides.question: Which of these vowels MUST be long?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! These are all vowels that must be long.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite Remember that ω and η can only be long vowels. The short vowels are α, ε, ι, ο, υ.

slides.title: Accents
slides.question: Which of these words contains an acute accent?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! The ό in ὁδός has an acute accent.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite Remember, the acute accent points right: ´ .

slides.title: Accents
slides.question: Which of these words contains a circumflex accent?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! The ῶ in σῶμα has a circumflex accent.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite Remember, the circumflex is crazy and wavy: ῀

slides.title: Accents
slides.question: Which of these words contains a grave accent?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! The ὸ in ὑπὸ has a grave accent.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite Remember, the grave accent points to the left: `

slides.title: Know your Greek!
slides.question: Select all the characteristics of a Noun in Ancient Greek.
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! When you see a noun, you'll need to figure out these three characteristics.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite Nouns in Greek have three characteristics: Gender, Number, and Case.

slides.title: Exercise: Pick the correct definite article
slides.question: Which definite article ("the") corresponds to feminine nouns, such as ἡμέρα (day)?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! The definite article for feminine nouns like ἡμέρα is ἡ.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite

slides.title: Exercise: Pick the correct definite article
slides.question: Which definite article ("the") corresponds to masculine nouns, such as πόλεμος (battle)?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! The definite article for masculine nouns like πόλεμος is ὁ.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite

slides.title: Exercise: Pick the correct definite article
slides.question: Which definite article ("the") corresponds to neuter nouns, such as ἔργον (work)?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! The definite article for neuter nouns like ἔργον is τό.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite

slides.title: Know your Greek!
slides.question: Which definite article ("the") agrees with plural, feminine nouns like ἡμέραι ("days")?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! You noticed that the ending of the article and the noun itself match!
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite Look at the endings and see how they're similar: αἱ ἡμέραι ("the days").

slides.title: Exercise: Select the Subject of this Sentence
slides.question: Which of these words is the subject of the following English sentence:
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! "The Ships" is the subject of this sentence, because it performs the action of the verb, "sailed". If this sentence were in Greek, "The ships" would be in the nominative case.
slides.hintMsg: Not quite.

slides.title: Exercise: Select the Complement of this Sentence
slides.question: Which of these words is the complement to the subject?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! You noticed that 'long' is the complement to the subject, 'the day'.
slides.hintMsg: Not quite.

slides.title: Exercise: Pick the Correct Case
slides.question: In which case does the subject of a sentence belong?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! Subjects of a sentence always belong in the nominative case.
slides.hintMsg: Not quite.

slides.title: Exercise: Select the Direct Object
slides.question: In the following sentence, which word or words are the direct object, and would belong in the accusative case if they were written in Greek?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer!
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite

slides.title: Exercise: Select the Direct Object
slides.question: Which of these words is in the accusative case?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer!
slides.hintMsg: Not quite.

slides.title: Make the forms agree!
slides.question: What is the accusative plural form for "the small country"?
slides.successMsg: Right Answer! The accusative plural form of 'the small country' is τὰς μῑκρὰς χώρᾱς.
slides.hintMsg: Not Quite
